## Supervised Learning: Model


- The input vector $x$ contains the interesting features which are measured to
  build the model. This features are often called independent variables,
  explanatory variables, regressors, controlled variables, ...

- After finding a function $\hat{f}$ which suits the data we can map a new
  input $x_0$ to an estimated output $\hat{y}$:
  \[
  \hat{y} = \hat{f}(x_0)
  \]

```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.height=2.7}
ggplot(iris, aes(Petal.Length, Petal.Width)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess") +
  annotate("text", x = 7, y = 2.25, label = "hat(f)", parse = TRUE, color = "blue",
    size = 6) +
  annotate("segment", x = 5, xend = 5, y = 0.1, yend = 1.76, size = 1,
    color = "dark red") +
  annotate("segment", x = 1.1, xend = 5, y = 1.76, yend = 1.76, size = 1,
    color = "dark red") +
  annotate("text", x = 5, y = -0.1, label = "x[0]", parse = TRUE,
    color = "dark red", size = 5) +
  annotate("text", x = 0.95, y = 1.76, label = "hat(y)", parse = TRUE,
    color = "dark red", size = 5)
```


## Supervised Learning: Model

Mathematically, we face a problem of function approximation: search for an
$f$, such that, for all points in the training data, and also all newly
observed points \[ y \approx f(x)\]
